did.abstract: Roberta Wood (1949-) has served as Secretary Treasurer of the Communist Party since 2007 and is a lifelong rank and file union activist. The Roberta Wood Collection consists of materials collected by Wood over the course of her decades of labor and political activism.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Roberta Wood in 2012; additional materials were donated in 2014. The accession number related to these gifts is 2012.082.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Roberta Wood (1949-) has served as Secretary Treasurer of the Communist Party since 2007. A lifelong rank and file union activist, Roberta co-founded the steelworker women's caucus in the in the Chicago/Gary district of the Steelworkers union. In 1976 she was elected the first female member of USWA Local 65's Executive Board. Following the closing of US Steel's South Works mill, Roberta worked until retirement as an electrical instrumentation mechanic in a municipal sewage treament facility. She served several years as labor editor of the People's Weekly World, forerunner to the People's World.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Roberta Wood Collection consists of materials collected by Wood over the course of her decades of labor and political activism. The collection is mostly comprised of financial statements, publicity, and planning materials from the Labor Education Fund's tribute for Florence Reece and the Ernesto De Maio Tribute Committee's tribute for Ernie De Maio, both in the 1970s. The collection also contains an oral history with Roberta Wood conducted in 2012 and biographies of numerous leaders in the labor, civil rights, and peace movements, collected for the Unity Center's (likely unpublished) Honor Roll and Golden Book of the Working Class. There are also notes and slides from the World Assembly of Builders of Peace Meeting in Warsaw, Poland in 1977.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Roberta Wood, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
